comments.html:
I just recently implemented QoS on my MPLS WAN. It is a beautiful thing.

I have four queues set up.

Queue 1 - Priority voice queue (equals 20% of the link)
Queue 2 - Mission Critical Traffic (equals 25%)
Queue 3 - Transactional Traffic (equals 20%)
Queue 4 - Default Queue or Everything Else (10%)

It really depends on your business needs as what goes in which queue. But my links can reach 90% utilization(large downloads) but the site doesn't notice any performance impact because as soon as they need something business critical policing will kick in. QoS will make a happy network engineer.
comments.name: John P

comments.html:
Hey Ivan,

Great post. It's a nice change to see someone who actually gets that QoS is a set of tools, not a thing that you can support or not. I may be dating myself here, but you left out LFI and Link Efficiency tools from the list. cRTP was bad back in the day.

Chris
comments.name: Chris Young

comments.html:
Great point. My blog wouldn't be as good as it is without my careful readers 8-)

Thank you. Will fix!
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: I would guess the same queuing setup has to be configured on the SP side (on the P-router). Right?
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: I was just thinking; Not sure how riverbed would with been called a link efficiency tool... Might be fun to try though?
comments.name: Chris young

comments.html: End-to-End QOS Design by Tim Szigeti was one of the best books I ever read on QOS. He really breaks down each tool and how they work together. Recommend for anyone getting their feet wet with QOS. (Honestly one of the most well written Cisco Press books I've read....just after MPLS and VPN Architectures)
comments.name: Matthew Stone

comments.html:
Like zipping a JPEG? Even TCP header compression is questionable as they probably totally mangle the TCP header.

BTW, I do have a single data point: Riverbed cannot use anything close to the full shaping bandwidth if you use low burst sizes (that don't affect regular TCP at all).
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Absolutely.  If your QoS profile does not match that of the SP, they may not necessarily honor the volume of marked traffic that you throw at them.
comments.name: anonymous

comments.html: I'm more concerned about PE-to-CE queuing. That's where congestion usually happens on low-speed remote sites.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
Woops I forgot to check for replies.

You are exactly correct. I am actually able to edit my PE queues and what qualifies for the queues.
comments.name: John P

comments.html:
I am a beginner and my query is regarding catalyst fixed configuration switches Architecture.

What is internal switch ring and what is it primarily used for?
What is the fabric type being implemented? Is it shared bus or cross bar fabric?

Port ASICs is said to have connected to a group of switch ports.
In Switches having multiple Port ASICs, how a packet from a switch port on a Port ASIC will be sent to a switch port on other Port ASIC?

Thank you
